articles.headline: Obama Weighs ‘Limited’ Strikes Against Syrian Forces
articles.snippet: President Obama is exploring a range of military actions against Syria designed to “deter and degrade” the ability of President Bashar al-Assad’s regime to launch chemical weapons, officials said.
articles.abstract: President Obama is exploring a range of military actions against Syria designed to “deter and degrade” the ability of President Bashar al-Assad’s regime to launch chemical weapons, officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama is considering military action against Syria that is intended to “deter and degrade” President Bashar al-Assad’s government’s ability to launch chemical weapons, but is not aimed at ousting Mr. Assad from power or forcing him to the negotiating table, administration officials said Tuesday.
articles.byline: By Thom Shanker, C. J. Chivers and Michael R. Gordon

articles.headline: Across China, Skyscrapers Brush the Heavens
articles.snippet: China is home to 60 of the world’s 100 tallest buildings now under construction, but the scale and speed of the projects have caused concern.
articles.abstract: China is home to 60 of the world’s 100 tallest buildings now under construction, but the scale and speed of the projects have caused concern.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHANGSHA, China — China is slowing down, but the buildings keep going up — until now.

articles.headline: Times Site Is Disrupted in Attack by Hackers
articles.snippet: The site was unavailable to readers Tuesday afternoon, the result of “a malicious external attack.”
articles.abstract: The site was unavailable to readers Tuesday afternoon, the result of “a malicious external attack.”
articles.lead_paragraph: The New York Times Web site was unavailable to readers on Tuesday afternoon after an online attack on the company’s domain name registrar. The attack also forced employees of The Times to take care in sending e-mails.
articles.byline: By Christine Haughney and Nicole Perlroth

articles.headline: Lessons in Maryland for Costs at Hospitals
articles.snippet: Maryland’s price-regulated hospitals fit a core objective of federal health care reform: changing hospitals and related facilities into something resembling an Accountable Care Organization.
articles.abstract: Maryland’s price-regulated hospitals fit a core objective of federal health care reform: changing hospitals and related facilities into something resembling an Accountable Care Organization.
articles.lead_paragraph: CUMBERLAND, Md. — This hardscrabble city at the base of the Appalachians makes for an unlikely hotbed of health care innovation.

articles.headline: Regulators Prepare Penalties for JPMorgan
articles.snippet: Federal regulators are preparing separate enforcement actions and fines against JPMorgan Chase stemming from the way it collected overdue bills from consumers during the recession in the latest legal woe facing the nation’s biggest bank.
articles.abstract: Federal regulators are preparing separate enforcement actions and fines against JPMorgan Chase stemming from the way it collected overdue bills from consumers during the recession in the latest legal woe facing the nation’s biggest bank.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two federal regulators are preparing a series of enforcement actions and fines against JPMorgan Chase stemming from its dealings with consumers during the recession, presenting the latest legal threat to the nation’s biggest bank.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Ben Protess

articles.headline: Merrill Lynch in Big Payout for Bias Case
articles.snippet: Merrill Lynch has agreed to pay $160 million to settle a racial bias lawsuit that wound through the federal courts for eight years, including two appeals to the United States Supreme Court.
articles.abstract: Merrill Lynch has agreed to pay $160 million to settle a racial bias lawsuit that wound through the federal courts for eight years, including two appeals to the United States Supreme Court.
articles.lead_paragraph: Merrill Lynch, one of the biggest brokerage firms on Wall Street, has agreed to pay $160 million to settle a racial bias lawsuit that wound through the federal courts for eight years, including two appeals to the United States Supreme Court.

articles.headline: In Advent of the Smartwatch, a Name That’s Been There Before
articles.snippet: The digital watch market, long dominated by Casio’s G-Shock line, is undergoing a transformation with a wave of innovative, multifunction gadgets.
articles.abstract: The digital watch market, long dominated by Casio’s G-Shock line, is undergoing a transformation with a wave of innovative, multifunction gadgets.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Clunky? Perhaps. Geeky? Absolutely. But for three decades Casio Computer’s G-Shock line of digital watches has dominated a small, yet lucrative, market.

articles.headline: The Lasting Power of Dr. King’s Dream Speech
articles.snippet: The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.’s “I Have a Dream” speech, which turns 50 on Wednesday, exerts a potent hold on people across generations.
articles.abstract: The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.’s “I Have a Dream” speech, which turns 50 on Wednesday, exerts a potent hold on people across generations.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was late in the day and hot, and after a long march and an afternoon of speeches about federal legislation, unemployment and racial and social justice, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. finally stepped to the lectern, in front of the Lincoln Memorial, to address the crowd of 250,000 gathered on the National Mall.

articles.headline: Salmonella in Spices Prompts Changes in Farming
articles.snippet: The United States Food and Drug Administration’s finding that imported spices are a surprisingly potent source of salmonella poisoning has prompted India to change how they are grown and harvested.
articles.abstract: The United States Food and Drug Administration’s finding that imported spices are a surprisingly potent source of salmonella poisoning has prompted India to change how they are grown and harvested.
articles.lead_paragraph: IDUKKI, India — Spices grown in the mist-shrouded Western Ghats here have fueled wars, fortunes and even the discovery of continents, and for thousands of years farmers harvested them in the same traditional ways. Until now.

articles.headline: Arab League Stance Muddies U.S. Case
articles.snippet: The leaders of the Arab world blamed the Syrian government for a chemical weapons attack, but declined to back a retaliatory military strike.
articles.abstract: The leaders of the Arab world blamed the Syrian government for a chemical weapons attack, but declined to back a retaliatory military strike.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The leaders of the Arab world on Tuesday blamed the Syrian government for a chemical weapons attack that killed hundreds of people last week, but declined to back a retaliatory military strike, leaving President Obama without the broad regional support he had for his last military intervention in the Middle East, in Libya in 2011.
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick and Mark Landler

articles.headline: Figuring Out What Time Is the Right Time to Start Hiring
articles.snippet: Business can come and go unexpectedly for small, private companies, and so experience offers the best lessons on when to hire new employees.
articles.abstract: Business can come and go unexpectedly for small, private companies, and so experience offers the best lessons on when to hire new employees.
articles.lead_paragraph: It can be challenging for Willan Johnson to know how many people to employ at his pool-cleaning business, VivoPools, in Los Angeles, for a number of reasons.

articles.headline: Nintendo Cuts a Dimension From a Device Aimed at Youths
articles.snippet: The Nintendo 2DS will cost $130, about $40 less than its 3DS sibling, as part of a strategy to prevent households from relying on tablets for video games.
articles.abstract: The Nintendo 2DS will cost $130, about $40 less than its 3DS sibling, as part of a strategy to prevent households from relying on tablets for video games.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Nintendo’s portable video game device, the 3DS, is selling well. But a plan to court children has the Japanese company cutting prices.

articles.headline: A Better Way to Bring Your Desktop to Your iPad
articles.snippet: The new Parallels Access app eases the compatibility obstacles between the tablet and a Mac or PC computer.
articles.abstract: The new Parallels Access app eases the compatibility obstacles between the tablet and a Mac or PC computer.
articles.lead_paragraph: You don’t have to be a technophile to know a few things about compatibility. VHS tapes don’t play on a laptop, iPhone apps don’t run on your microwave and a CD won’t play in a toaster.
